args:
Chapter 3 Digital FTE Strategy Restructure - Issue #386

## Feature Summary
Restructure Chapter 3 from "Billion Dollar AI" to "The Digital FTE Strategy" to align with the Agent Factory vision and eliminate redundancy with the updated Chapter 1.

## Context
- Chapter 1 has been updated with comprehensive Agent Factory content (10 lessons covering General vs Custom Agents, Digital FTE Vision, Spec-Driven Development, etc.)
- Chapter 3 currently has significant overlap with Chapter 1 content
- Agent Factory slides contain monetization content NOT yet in the book
- Issue #386 requests alignment with Digital FTE / Agent Factory strategy

## Requirements

### Structural Changes
1. Rename folder from `03-billion-dollar-ai/` to `03-digital-fte-strategy/`
2. Restructure from 8 lessons to 10 lessons
3. Add 2 NEW lessons:
   - Lesson 5: "Four Monetization Models" (from slides Part 11)
   - Lesson 8: "When NOT to Use AI Agents" (from slides Part 15)

### Lesson Updates
1. Lesson 1: Reframe from "Billion Dollar Question" to "Your Expertise as Product" - remove redundancy with Ch1, add personal application focus
2. Lesson 2: Keep "Snakes and Ladders" - minor terminology alignment
3. Lesson 3: Reframe from "Super Orchestrators" to "The FTE Advantage" - remove Digital FTE table (now in Ch1 L10), add sales presentation tips
4. Lesson 4: Significant update to "Vertical Intelligence" - add Agent Skills/SKILL.md content from slides
5. Lesson 5: NEW "Four Monetization Models" - Subscription, Success Fee, License, Marketplace
6. Lesson 6: Keep "PPP Strategy" - minor edits
7. Lesson 7: Keep "Three Requirements" (renumbered from 6)
8. Lesson 8: NEW "When NOT to Use AI Agents" - security, compliance, common pitfalls
9. Lesson 9: Update "Pause and Reflect" - new monetization-focused prompts
10. Lesson 10: Update Quiz - add 15 new questions on monetization, Agent Skills, guardrails

### Content Sources
- Agent Factory slides Part 11 (Pages 63-64): Monetization models
- Agent Factory slides Part 15 (Pages 84-87): Security, compliance, pitfalls
- Agent Factory slides Part 6 (Pages 37-50): Agent Skills/SKILL.md
- Agent Factory slides Part 12 (Pages 71-73): Digital FTE economics, sales tips

### Success Criteria
- Zero redundancy with Chapter 1 content
- All 4 monetization models clearly explained with examples
- Agent Skills/SKILL.md format documented
- "When NOT to use" guardrails included
- Quiz covers new content areas
- All .summary.md files regenerated

### Non-Goals
- Not restructuring other chapters
- Not adding code examples (conceptual chapter)
- Not changing the fundamental Snakes & Ladders or PPP frameworks

### Dependencies
- Chapter 1 Agent Factory Paradigm (completed)
- Chapter 2 AIFF Foundation (#385 - in progress, but independent)

Chapter 39: Agent Skills & MCP Code Execution

## Context
This chapter is in Part 6 (AI-Native Software Development). Students have completed:
- Chapter 5: Claude Code Skills fundamentals (SKILL.md, MCP integration basics as USER)
- Chapter 38: Custom MCP Servers (building MCP servers)

This chapter bridges Skills and MCP to enable BUILDER capability - taking students from using skills/MCP to creating and shipping them.

## Official Sources
- AgentSkills.io: https://agentskills.io/integrate-skills (open format for AI agent skills)
- MCP Official: https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/getting-started/intro
- E2B MCP for code execution: https://e2b.dev/docs/mcp
- Anthropic code execution pattern: https://www.anthropic.com/engineering/code-execution-with-mcp

## Chapter Structure from README
8 lessons covering:
1. Skills Architecture Deep Dive — SKILL.md structure, persona patterns, Questions + Principles
2. Skill Composition Patterns — Dependencies, inheritance, skill libraries
3. Code Execution Fundamentals — Why sandboxing, execution models, security
4. MCP Code Execution Servers — E2B, Code Interpreter, Docker sandboxes
5. Execution Workflow Patterns — Write-execute-analyze loops, error recovery
6. Safety & Resource Management — CPU/memory limits, network policies, timeouts
7. Skills + Execution Integration — Skills for strategy, code execution for tactics
8. Capstone: Data Analysis Agent — Spec-driven agent using skills + code execution

## Key Differentiator from Chapter 5
- Chapter 5: USING skills and MCP (consumer perspective)
- Chapter 39: BUILDING and SHIPPING skills + code execution (builder perspective)

## Existing Skills to Leverage
- .claude/skills/mcp-builder - comprehensive MCP server building guide
- .claude/skills/creating-skills - skill creation patterns

## Output Path
/Users/mjs/Documents/code/panaversity-official/tutorsgpt/mcp-3/specs/chapter-39-agent-skills-mcp-execution

Chapter 34: OpenAI Agents SDK - Build production agents with OpenAI's official Python SDK. Covers: 1) SDK setup and first agent, 2) Function tools deep dive, 3) Multi-agent handoffs, 4) Guardrails and safety, 5) Streaming and async patterns, 6) Tracing and observability, 7) Capstone: Customer support system. Must include LiteLLM integration for free/alternative model usage in at least one lesson. Uses building-with-openai-agents skill as knowledge source. Running example: TaskManager agent from Part 6.

Chapter 35: Google Agent Development Kit (ADK) - This chapter teaches building custom AI agents that are reliable, safe, and evaluated on real tasks using Google's ADK framework. The chapter builds on Chapter 34 (OpenAI SDK) to show how the same agent patterns manifest in Google's ecosystem. Key topics: ADK setup with Gemini/Vertex AI, Agent types (LlmAgent, SequentialAgent, ParallelAgent, LoopAgent), Tools (FunctionTool, AgentTool, McpToolset), Session management, Guardrails and callbacks, Evaluation with adk eval, Deployment to Vertex AI Agent Engine and Cloud Run. The running example is TaskManager Agent.

Chapter 35: Google Agent Development Kit (ADK) - This chapter teaches building custom AI agents that are reliable, safe, and evaluated on real tasks using Google's ADK framework. The chapter builds on Chapter 34 (OpenAI SDK) to show how the same agent patterns manifest in Google's ecosystem. Key topics: ADK setup with Gemini/Vertex AI, Agent types (LlmAgent, SequentialAgent, ParallelAgent, LoopAgent), Tools (FunctionTool, AgentTool, McpToolset), Session management, Guardrails and callbacks, Evaluation with adk eval, Deployment to Vertex AI Agent Engine and Cloud Run.

Chapter 36: Claude Agent SDK - Building Digital FTEs

## Context from Research (Phase A)
- Skill created: .claude/skills/building-with-claude-agent-sdk
- Official docs: platform.claude.com/docs/en/agent-sdk/*
- The SDK enables building AI agents with the same tools that power Claude Code
- NO API KEY PROVIDED - all examples must be documented/conceptual, not executable

## Chapter Position
- Part 6: AI Native Software Development
- Chapter number: 36
- Directory: apps/learn-app/docs/06-AI-Native-Software-Development/36-anthropic-agents-kit-development/

## Running Example
TaskManager Agent - consistent with other SDK chapters in Part 6

## Key Topics from SDK Documentation
1. query() function and ClaudeAgentOptions
2. Built-in tools: Read, Edit, Write, Bash, Glob, Grep, WebSearch, WebFetch, Task
3. Permission modes: default, acceptEdits, bypassPermissions
4. Session management (resume, fork)
5. Subagents with AgentDefinition
6. Hooks (PreToolUse, PostToolUse, etc.)
7. Custom MCP tools with @tool decorator and create_sdk_mcp_server
8. ClaudeSDKClient for multi-turn conversations
9. Streaming input mode vs single-turn
10. Hosting patterns: ephemeral, long-running, hybrid

## Differentiation from Chapter 5 (Claude Code Features)
- Chapter 5: Using Claude Code as an end-user tool
- Chapter 36: Programmatic SDK for building Custom Agents

## Reference Quality Lesson
apps/learn-app/docs/01-Introducing-AI-Driven-Development/01-agent-factory-paradigm/01-the-2025-inflection-point.md
